|related=[[Korean diaspora]], [[Koryo-saram]] }} {{Infobox East Asian |hangul={{linktext|사할린}} {{linktext|한국인}} |hanja=사할린 {{linktext|韓國人}} |rr=Sahallin Hangugin |cyrillic=Сахалинские корейцы or Корейцы Сахалина |romanization=Sakhalinskie Koreytsi or Koreytsi Sakhalina |russiantext= Literally, "Sakhalin Koreans" or "Koreans of Sakhalin" }} '''Sakhalin Koreans''' are Russian citizens and residents of Korean descent living on [[Sakhalin Island]], who trace their roots to the immigrants from the [[Gyeongsang]] and [[Jeolla]] provinces of [[Korea]] during the late 1930s and early 1940s, the latter half of the [[Korea under Japanese rule|Japanese colonial era]]. At the time, the southern half of Sakhalin Island, then known as [[Karafuto Prefecture]], was under the control of the [[Empire of Japan]]; the Japanese government both recruited and forced Korean labourers into service and shipped them to Karafuto to fill labour shortages resulting from [[World War II]]. The [[Red Army]] invaded Karafuto days before [[Surrender of Japan|Japan's surrender]]; while all but a few Japanese there [[repatriate]]d successfully, almost one-third of the Koreans could not secure permission to depart either to Japan or their home towns in [[South Korea]]. For the next forty years, they lived in exile. In 1985, the Japanese government offered transit rights and funding for the repatriation of the original group of Sakhalin Koreans; however, only 1,500 of them returned to South Korea in the next two decades. The vast majority of Koreans of all generations chose instead to stay on Sakhalin. Due to differing language and immigration history, Sakhalin Koreans may or may not identify themselves as [[Koryo-saram]]. The term "Koryo-saram" may be used to encompass to all Koreans in the [[Post-Soviet States|former USSR]], but typically refers to ethnic Koreans from [[Hamgyŏng]] province whose ancestors emigrated to the [[Russian Far East]] in the 19th century, and then were later [[Deportation of Koreans in the Soviet Union|deported to Central Asia]]. The issue of self-identification is complicated by the fact that many Sakhalin Koreans feel that Koreans from [[Central Asia]] look down on them.{{cite news|last=Ban|first=Byung-yool|title=Koreans in Russia: Historical Perspective|date=2004-09-22|accessdate=2006-11-20|url=http://times.hankooki.com/lpage/nation/200409/kt2004092218583111950.htm|work=Korea Times|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050318164348/http://times.hankooki.com/lpage/nation/200409/kt2004092218583111950.htm|archivedate=2005-03-18}} ==History== === Under Japanese colonialism === ==== Origins ==== [[File:KarafutoMassacresMap.png|frame|right|Approximate locations of the massacres
1: [[Shikuka]], near Kamishisuka (上敷香)
2: [[Maoka]], near Mizuho Village (瑞穂村)
{{legend|#AE4242|[[Soviet Union]]|border=1px solid black}} {{legend|#E7D67B|[[Empire of Japan]]|border=1px solid black}}]] Korean immigration to Sakhalin began as early as the 1910s, when the [[Mitsui Group]] began recruiting labourers from the peninsula for their mining operations.{{cite journal|last=Miki|first=Masafumi|title=戦間期樺太における朝鮮人社会の形成―『在日』朝鮮人史研究の空間性をめぐって (The formation of the Korean community in inter-war Karafuto)|journal=社会経済史学 (Socio-economic History)|volume=68|publisher=Socio-Economic History Society, Waseda University|issue=2|language=ja}} In 1920, ten years after the [[Japan-Korea Annexation Treaty|annexation of Korea by Japan]], there were fewer than one thousand Koreans in the whole of Karafuto Prefecture, overwhelmingly male.{{cite journal|author=Kim, German Nikolaevich|date=2004-12-09|accessdate=2006-11-26|url=http://world.lib.ru/k/kim_o_i/str1rtf.shtml|publisher=[[Al-Farabi University]]|location=Kazakhstan|title=Корейцы на Сахалине (Koreans in Sakhalin)|authorlink=German Kim|language=ru}} Aside from an influx of refugees from the [[Primorsky Krai|Maritimes]], who escaped to [[Karafuto]] during the [[Russian Revolution of 1917]], the number of Koreans in the province did not rise very rapidly; as late as the mid-1930s, there were fewer than 6,000 Koreans in Karafuto.{{cite journal|last=Morris-Suzuki|first=Tessa|title=Northern Lights: The Making and Unmaking of Karafuto Identity|journal=Journal of Asian Studies|volume=60|issue=3|pages=645–671|doi=10.2307/2700105|date=August 2001|jstor=2700105|publisher=Association for Asian Studies}} However, as Japan's war effort picked up, the Japanese government sought to put more people on the ground in the sparsely-populated prefecture in order to ensure their control of the territory and fill the increasing demands of the coal mines and lumber yards. Recruiters turned to sourcing workers from the Korean peninsula; at one point, over 150,000 Koreans were relocated to work on the island.{{cite news|last=Lee|first=Jin-woo|title=3,100 Sakhalin Koreans yearn to return home|publisher=The Korea Times|date=2005-02-18|accessdate=2006-11-26|url=http://times.hankooki.com/lpage/nation/200502/kt2005021817362210580.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070102055241/http://times.hankooki.com/lpage/nation/200502/kt2005021817362210580.htm|archivedate=2007-01-02}} Of those, around 10,000 mine workers were relocated to Japan prior to the war's end; present-day Sakhalin Koreans' efforts to locate them proved futile.{{cite news|title=Sakhalin Koreans celebrate 60th anniversary of liberation from Japanese bondage |url=http://www.thesakhalintimes.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1815 |publisher=The Sakhalin Times |date=2005-08-26 |accessdate=2006-11-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928002750/http://www.thesakhalintimes.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1815 |archivedate=2007-09-28 |df= }} The [[Imperial Japanese Army]] in Karafuto frequently used local ethnic minorities ([[Orok people|Oroks]], [[Nivkh people|Nivkhs]], and [[Ainu people|Ainu]]) to conduct intelligence-gathering activities, because, as indigenous inhabitants, their presence would not arouse suspicion on the Soviet half of the island. Ethnic Koreans could also be found on both sides of the border, but the use of Koreans as spies was not common, as the Karafuto police were wary of the support for the [[Korean independence movement|independence movement]] among Koreans. Soviet suspicion towards Korean nationalism, along with fears that the Korean community might harbour Japanese spies, led to the 1937 [[Deportation of Koreans in the Soviet Union|deportation of Koreans]] from Soviet-controlled northern Sakhalin and the [[Russian Far East]].{{cite conference|last=Choe|first=Gil-seong|title=樺太における日本人の朝鮮人虐殺 (The Japanese Massacre of Koreans in Karafuto)|booktitle=世界法史の単一性と複数性 (Unity and complexity of international legal history)|pages=289–296|publisher=Miraisha|year=2005|language=ja}} ====Soviet invasion and Japanese massacres==== The Soviet Union invaded the Japanese portion of Sakhalin on August 11, 1945, resulting the deaths of 20,000 civilians (see [[Soviet–Japanese War (1945)]]). In the confusion that ensued, a rumour began to spread that ethnic Koreans could be serving as spies for the Soviet Union, and led to massacres of Koreans by Japanese police and civilians. Despite the generally limited amount of information about the massacres, two examples of massacres are comparatively well-known today: the incident in Kamishisuka (now Leonidovo) on August 18, 1945, and the incident in Mizuho Village (now Pozharskoye), which lasted from August 20 to August 23, 1945. In Kamishisuka, the Japanese police arrested 19 Koreans on charges of spy activities; 18 were found shot within the police station the next day.{{cite web|url=http://www.aurora-net.or.jp/user/tamura/sakha2-13.htm|script-title=ja:サハリンレポートによる記事|accessdate=2006-11-27|language=ja}} Has photos. The sole survivor, a Korean known only by his [[sōshi-kaimei|Japanese name]] Nakata, had survived by hiding in a toilet; he later offered testimony about the event.{{cite book|last=Hayashi|first=Eidai|title=証言・樺太(サハリン)朝鮮人虐殺事件 (Testimony: The Massacre of Karafuto/Sakhalin Koreans)|year=1992|publisher=Fubaisha|language=ja}} In Mizuho Village, Japanese fleeing Soviet troops who had landed at Maoka (now [[Kholmsk]]) claimed that the Koreans were cooperating with the Red Army and that they were pillaging Japanese property. Though Koreans and Japanese worked alongside each other in the village on farms and construction projects, the Japanese civilians turned against their Korean neighbors, killing 27 between August 20 and 23. Other individual Koreans may have been killed to cover up evidence of Japanese atrocities committed during the evacuation: one woman interviewed by a US-Russian joint commission investigating the issue of Allied prisoners of war held by the [[Imperial Japanese Army]] in [[List of Japanese POW camps during World War II|camps on Sakhalin]] reported that her ethnic Korean lover had been murdered by Japanese troops after he had witnessed mass shootings of hundreds of American prisoners of war.{{cite journal|url=http://memory.loc.gov/frd/tfrussia/tfrhtml/tfrsplit/tfr010.html|title=Task Force Russia -- Biweekly Report 19 December 1982 - 8 January 1993 (12th Report)|publisher=U.S.-Russian Joint Delegation on POWs/MIAs|date=1993-01-08|accessdate=2007-02-21}} === Integration into the Soviet Union === ==== Repatriation refused ==== In the years after the Soviet invasion, most of the 400,000 Japanese civilians who had not already been [[Evacuation of Karafuto and Kuriles|evacuated during the war]] left voluntarily under the auspices of the US-USSR Agreement on Repatriation of those left in the USSR, signed in December 1946. Many of the 150,000 Koreans on the island safely returned to mainland Japan, and some went to the northern half of the Korean peninsula; however, roughly 43,000 were not accepted for repatriation by Japan, and also could not be repatriated to the southern half of the Korean peninsula due to the political situation; The Soviet government initially had drawn up plans to repatriate the Koreans along with the Japanese, but the local administration on Sakhalin objected, arguing that incoming Russians from the mainland would not be sufficient to replace the skilled labourers who had already departed. The indecision about the ultimate fate of the Sakhalin Koreans persisted until the outbreak of the [[Korean War]], after which repatriation became a political impossibility.{{cite news|last=Lankov|first=Andrei|work=Russia Beyond the Headlines|date=2013-08-01|accessdate=2013-08-01|title=How 25 thousand miners were marooned on a distant island|url=http://rbth.asia/blogs/2013/08/01/how_25_thausand_miners_were_marooned_on_a_distant_island_48317.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.li/20130802030734/http://rbth.asia/blogs/2013/08/01/how_25_thausand_miners_were_marooned_on_a_distant_island_48317.html|archivedate=2013-08-02|df=}} Some sources claim Stalin himself blocked their departure because he wanted to retain them as coal miners on the island.{{cite news|last=Lankov|first=Andrei|work=The Korea Times|date=2006-01-05|accessdate=2006-11-26|title=Stateless in Sakhalin|url=http://times.hankooki.com/lpage/opinion/200601/kt2006010516434554130.htm}} In 1957, Seoul appealed for Tokyo's assistance to secure the departure of ethnic Koreans from Sakhalin via Japan, but Tokyo took no real action on the request, and blamed Soviet intransigence for the lack of progress in resolving the issue; Japan continued its earlier policy of granting entrance only to Sakhalin Koreans who were married to Japanese citizens, or had a Japanese parent.{{cite news|title=Japan refused to help Koreans leave Sakhalin|date=2000-12-19|work=Kyodo News|accessdate=2013-08-01|url=http://www.news.ch/Japan+refused+to+help+Koreans+leave+Sakhalin+island/26316/detail.htm}} During the late 1940s, the ranks of ethnic Koreans on the island were augmented by another 8,000 North Korean expatriates, recruited by the Soviet government to work in state-owned fisheries.{{Cite news|url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2009/12/120_54137.html|date=2009-10-23|accessdate=2010-01-08|periodical=Korea Times|last=Lankov|first=Andrei|title=N. Korean Mirage Collapses in Sakhalin}} In an effort to integrate the Korean labourers, who were unfamiliar with the Soviet system and unable to speak Russian, local authorities set up schools using the Korean language as the medium of instruction. However, the Sakhalin Koreans were believed to have been "infected with the Japanese spirit", and so for the most part the authorities did not trust them to run any of their own collective farms, mills, factories, schools, or hospitals. Instead, these tasks were left to several hundred [[Koryo-saram|ethnic Koreans imported from Central Asia]], who were bilingual in Russian and Korean. Resentment towards the social dominance of Koreans from Central Asia over the Sakhalin Koreans led to tensions between the two groups; the latter developed a number of disparaging terms in Korean to refer to the former.{{cite journal|url=http://mion.isu.ru/pub/russ-ost/diaspr/6.html|title=Актуальные проблемы корейской диаспоры в Центральной Азии (Important problems of the Korean diaspora in Central Asia)|last=Kim|first=German|author2=Khan, Valery |publisher=Kazakh State University|year=2001|accessdate=2007-04-27}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite conference|last=Um|first=Hae-kyung |editor=K. Schulze |editor2=M. Stokes |editor3=C. Campbell |year=1996|title=The Korean diaspora in Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan: social change, identity and music-making|booktitle=Nationalism, minorities and diasporas: identities and rights in the Middle East|publisher=Tauris|location=London|pages=217–232}} The Sakhalin government's policy towards the Sakhalin Koreans continued to shift in line with bilateral relations between North Korea and the Soviet Union. During the 1950s, [[North Korea]] demanded that the Soviets treat Sakhalin Koreans as [[Nationality Law of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea|North Korean citizens]], and, through their consulate, even set up study groups and other educational facilities for them (analogous to [[Chongryon]]'s similar, more successful efforts among the [[Zainichi Koreans]]). During the late 1950s, it became increasingly difficult for the Sakhalin Koreans to obtain Soviet citizenship, and a growing proportion chose instead to become North Korean citizens rather to than deal with the burdens of remaining stateless, which included severe restrictions on their freedom of movement and the requirement to apply for permission from the local government in order to travel outside of Sakhalin. As of 1960, only 25% had been able to secure Soviet citizenship; 65% had declared North Korean citizenship, with the remaining 10% choosing to remain unaffiliated despite the difficulties this entailed.{{cite book|last=Ishikida|first=Miki|title=Toward Peace: War Responsibility, Postwar Compensation, and Peace Movements and Education in Japan|year=2005|publisher=Center for US-Japan Comparative Social Studies|isbn=0-595-35063-1}} However, as relations between the Soviet Union and North Korea deteriorated, the authorities acted to de-emphasise Korean language education and reduce the influence of North Korea within the community; by the early 1970s, Sakhalin Koreans were once again encouraged to apply for Soviet citizenship. ==== Attention from the outside world ==== In the late 1960s and early 1970s, the situation of the Sakhalin Koreans improved as the outside world began to pay much more attention to their situation. Starting in 1966, Park No Hak, a former Sakhalin Korean who had earlier received permission to leave Sakhalin and settle in Japan by virtue of his having a Japanese wife, petitioned the Japanese government a total of 23 times to discuss the issue of the Sakhalin Koreans with the Soviet government. His actions inspired 500,000 South Koreans to form an organisation to work towards the repatriation of their co-ethnics; in response, the South Korean began radio broadcasts targeted at the Sakhalin Koreans, in an effort to assure them that they had not been forgotten.{{cite book|last=Pak|first=Hyeong-ju|title=サハリンからのレポート―棄てられた朝鮮人の歴史と証言 (The Report From Sakhalin: History and Testimony of Discarded Koreans)|date=January 1991|publisher=Ochanomizu Shobo|language=ja}}{{cite news|title=The Forsaken People|date=1976-01-12|accessdate=2006-11-27|publisher=[[Time Magazine]]|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,913836,00.html}} At the same time, Rei Mihara, a Tokyo housewife, formed a similar pressure group in Japan, and 18 Japanese lawyers attempted to sue the Japanese government to force them to accept diplomatic and financial responsibility for the transportation of the Sakhalin Koreans and their return to South Korea. Additionally, the Soviet government finally began to permit the Sakhalin Koreans to naturalize. However, as many as 10% continued to refuse both Soviet and North Korean citizenship, and demanded repatriation to South Korea.{{cite journal|last=Stephan|first=John J|title=Sakhalin Island: Soviet Outpost in Northeast Asia|journal=Asian Survey|volume=10|issue=12|date=December 1970|pages=1090–1100|doi=10.1525/as.1970.10.12.01p00612}} By 1976, only 2,000 more of their population had been able to obtain permission to depart from Sakhalin, but that year, the Sakhalin government made a public announcement that people seeking to emigrate to South Korea could simply show up at the Immigration Office to file an application. Within a week, they had received more than 800 such applications, including some from North Korean citizens; this caused the North Korean embassy to complain to their Soviet counterparts about the new emigration policy. The Soviet authorities in the end chose for unspecified reasons to [[refusenik (Soviet Union)|refuse to issue exit visas]] to most of those concerned, leading to the unusual case of public demonstrations about the refusals by Korean families. This level of open dissent provoked the authorities to completely reverse their liberalising stance towards the Sakhalin Koreans; they arrested more than 40 protestors, and in November 1976 deported them, but to North Korea rather than to the South as they desired. Further purges and intimidation of those seeking to emigrate also followed. Through to the early 1980s, locally born Korean youth, increasingly interested in their heritage, were [[dual loyalty|seen as traitors]] by their Russian neighbours for wanting to know more about their ancestral land and for seeking to emigrate. The nadir of ethnic relations came after the 1983 shooting-down of [[Korean Air Lines Flight 007]] by the Soviet Union. === Perestroika, glasnost, and the post-Soviet period === ==== Improving relations with Japan ==== In 1985, Japan agreed to approve transit rights and fund the repatriation of the first generation of Sakhalin Koreans;{{cite news|title=Sakhalin Koreans discuss Japan strategy |publisher=The Sakhalin Times |url=http://www.thesakhalintimes.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=728 |date=2004-05-28 |accessdate=2006-11-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928002743/http://www.thesakhalintimes.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=728 |archivedate=2007-09-28 |df= }} the Soviet Union also began to liberalize their emigration laws in 1987.{{cite journal|last=Aronson|first=Geoffrey|title=Soviet Jewish Emigration, the United States, and the Occupied Territories|journal=Journal of Palestine Studies|volume= 19|date=Summer 1990|pages=30–45|doi=10.1525/jps.1990.19.4.00p0215c|issue= 4|jstor=2537387}} As of 2001, Japan spends [[United States dollar|US$]]1.2 million a year to fund Sakhalin Koreans' visits to Seoul. The Foreign Ministry allocated about $5 million to build a cultural centre in Sakhalin, which was intended to feature a library, an exhibition hall, Korean language classrooms, and other facilities, but {{As of|2004|lc=on}}, the project had not begun, causing protests among the Sakhalin Koreans. On April 18, 1990, [[Taro Nakayama]], Japan's [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Japan)|Minister for Foreign Affairs]], stated: : ''"Japan is deeply sorry for the tragedy in which these (Korean) people were moved to Sakhalin not of their own free will but by the design of the Japanese government and had to remain there after the conclusion of the war"''.{{cite web|title=第118回国会衆議院外務委員会議録3号 (118th National Diet Session Lower House Committee on Foreign Affairs #3) |date=1990-04-18 |accessdate=2006-11-26 |work=国会会議録検索システム (Diet Minutes Search System) |url=http://kokkai.ndl.go.jp |language=ja }} [http://home.att.ne.jp/sun/RUR55/E/epage16.htm Translation] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040904030526/http://home.att.ne.jp/sun/RUR55/E/epage16.htm |date=September 4, 2004 }} in Kenichi Takagi, Rethinking Japan's Postwar Compensation: Voices of Victims. tr. by Makiko Nakano. The foreign trade of Sakhalin with Japan is still roughly four times that with Korea,{{which|date=July 2018}} and Japanese companies greatly outnumber their Korean on the island.{{cite press release|title=Investment Climate|publisher=Economy Committee of Sakhalin|url=http://www.sakhipa.ru/index.php?id=71&L=1|year=2004|accessdate=2006-11-28|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930081834/http://www.sakhipa.ru/index.php?id=71&L=1|archivedate=2007-09-30|df=}} As a result, while members of the first generation still carry [[Anti-Japanese sentiment in Korea|anti-Japanese sentiment]], the younger generations have developed an interest in [[Japanese culture]] and have taken up the [[Japanese language education in Russia|study of the Japanese language]], much to the consternation of their elders.{{cite news|last=Baek|first=Il-hyun|title=Scattered Koreans turn homeward|date=2005-09-14|publisher=Joongang Daily|accessdate=2006-11-27|url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/200509/14/200509142129404979900091009101.html |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20051127093846/http://joongangdaily.joins.com/200509/14/200509142129404979900091009101.html |archivedate = November 27, 2005}} On October 28, 2006, a Korean student from the [[Sakhalin State University]] placed second in the All-[[Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]] Japanese Language Students Competition.{{cite web|script-title=ru:Жюри всероссийского конкурса японского языка присудило студентке СахГУ второе место |url=http://www.sakhgu.sakhalin.ru/ |year=2006 |publisher=[[Sakhalin State University]] |accessdate=2007-01-24 |language=ru |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070204012212/http://sakhgu.sakhalin.ru/ |archivedate=2007-02-04 |df= }} ==== North and South Korean influence ==== During the 1990s, commerce, communication, and direct flights opened up between Sakhalin and [[South Korea]], and the two Koreas began to vie openly for influence among the Sakhalin Koreans. Television and radio programmes from both North and South Korea, as well as local programming, began to be broadcast on [[Sakhalin Korean Broadcasting]], the only Korean television station in all of Russia.{{cite news|last=Jones |first=Lucy |title=Forgotten Prisoners |publisher=The Vladivostok News |date=1997-12-30 |accessdate=2006-11-26 |url=http://vn.vladnews.ru/Arch/1997/ISS157/NEWS.HTM |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061010041134/http://vn.vladnews.ru/Arch/1997/ISS157/NEWS.HTM |archivedate=2006-10-10 |df= }}{{cite news|last=Kim |first=Hyun |title=Wave of dramas from homeland uplifts Sakhalin Koreans |date=2005-07-08 |accessdate=2006-11-26 |publisher=Yonhap News |url=http://english.yna.co.kr/Engnews/20050708/500100000020050708120824E0.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927001305/http://english.yna.co.kr/Engnews/20050708/500100000020050708120824E0.html |archivedate=2007-09-27 |df= }} North Korea negotiated with Russia for closer economic relations with Sakhalin,{{cite news|title=North Korea calls for greater relations with Sakhalin|publisher=ITAR-TASS|date=2006-11-23|accessdate=2006-11-26|url=http://news.tradingcharts.com/futures/8/7/86078878.html}} and sponsored an art show in [[Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk]] in 2006.{{cite news|title=North Korean Art Exhibition being held in Sakhalin |url=http://www.thesakhalintimes.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=2922 |publisher=The Sakhalin Times |accessdate=2006-11-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061120170329/http://www.thesakhalintimes.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=2922 |archivedate=2006-11-20 |df= }} They have also permitted delegations of Sakhalin Koreans to visit relatives in North Korea. Scholarly studies suggest that roughly 1,000 Sakhalin Koreans have opted to repatriate to North Korea, but the rise of the South Korean economy combined with the ongoing economic and political turmoil in the North have made this option less attractive. Sakhalin Koreans have also provided assistance to [[North Korean defectors|refugees fleeing North Korea]], either those who illegally escaped across the border, or those who escaped North Korean labour camps in Russia itself.{{cite journal|title=Situation and Protection of North Korean Refugees in Russia|author=Yoon, Yeo-sang|publisher=Korea Political Development Research Center|url=http://www.nkhumanrights.or.kr/bbs/board2/files/57_yeo-sangyoon.doc|format=Microsoft Word|accessdate=2006-11-27 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060104012148/http://nkhumanrights.or.kr/bbs/board2/files/57_yeo-sangyoon.doc |archivedate = January 4, 2006}} South Korea and Japan jointly funded the building of a nursing home for elderly Sakhalin Koreans in [[Ansan]], a [[Seoul National Capital Area|suburb of Seoul]], and under the auspices of the [[Korean Red Cross]], 1,544 people had settled there and in other locations {{As of|2002|alt=by the end of 2002}}, while another 14,122 had travelled to South Korea on short-term visits at Japanese government expense.{{cite pressrelease|title=Inter-Korean Affairs: Family Reunions|url=http://redcross.or.kr/www/eng/service.jsp?pageindex=7|accessdate=2006-11-26|publisher=The Republic of Korea National Red Cross}} South Korean investors also began to participate in the international tenders for works contracts to develop the Sakhalin Shelf, as they are interested in the potential supply of [[liquefied natural gas]]. By the year 2000, South Korean missionaries had opened several churches, and South Koreans comprised the majority of [[international students]] at the [[Sakhalin State University]]. The [[Korean Residents' Association on Sakhalin]], an ethnic representative body, is generally described as being pro-South Korean, analogous to Japan's [[Mindan]].{{cite news|date=2000-10-02 |accessdate=2006-11-26 |title=Sakhalin's Koreans angry over delay in cultural center |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0XPQ/is_2000_Oct_2/ai_66169200 |publisher=Kyodo |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615175951/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0XPQ/is_2000_Oct_2/ai_66169200/ |archivedate=2011-06-15 |df= }} In addition to the elderly, a few younger Koreans have also chosen to move to South Korea, either to find their roots, or for economic reasons, as wages in South Korea are as much as three times those in Sakhalin. However, upon arrival, they often find that they are viewed as foreigners by the South Korean locals, despite their previous exposure to Korean culture in Sakhalin. As one returnee put it, "Sakhalin Koreans live in a different world than Sakhalin Russians but that world isn’t Korea".{{cite news|title=Transplanted Sakhaliner |url=http://www.thesakhalintimes.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=833 |publisher=The Sakhalin Times |date=2004-07-02 |accessdate=2006-11-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061120194431/http://www.thesakhalintimes.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=833 |archivedate=2006-11-20 |df= }} In general, younger Sakhalin Koreans, especially those lacking fluency in the Korean language, prefer to stay on Sakhalin.{{Cite news|periodical=Los Angeles Times|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/dec/30/news/adfg-khome30|title=Torn between two lands|last=Herman|first=Burt|date=2007-12-30|accessdate=2010-01-08}} Of the 1,544 Koreans who repatriated to South Korea {{As of|2005|lc=on}}, nearly 10% eventually returned to Sakhalin. Conversely, some foreign students from Korea studying in Sakhalin also reported difficulties in befriending local Koreans, claiming that the latter looked down on them for being foreigners.{{cite news|last=Yong |first=Kyeong Roo |title=Sakhalin's Three Sets of Koreans |url=http://www.thesakhalintimes.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1610 |date=2005-06-06 |accessdate=2006-11-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061120210623/http://www.thesakhalintimes.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1610 |archivedate=2006-11-20 |df= }} ==== Local interethnic relations ==== In the late 1980s, suspicions against the Sakhalin Koreans remained. With the relaxation of [[Propiska in the Soviet Union|internal migration controls]] and the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]], Russians began moving ''en masse'' back to the mainland, making ethnic Koreans an increasing proportion of the population; there were fears that they might become a majority of the island's population, and seek an [[Republics of Russia|autonomous republic]] or even independence.{{cite news|url=http://www.lgz.ru/archives/html_arch/lg122005/Polosy/20_1.htm |title=Помни имя своё |date=December 2005 |last=Stroev |first=Anatoly |work=Литературная газета (Literaturnaya Gazeta) |accessdate=2006-11-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100726162212/http://www.lgz.ru/archives/html_arch/lg122005/Polosy/20_1.htm |archivedate=2010-07-26 |df= }} However, the rise of the regional economy and the cultural assimilation of the younger generations drove more than 95% of Koreans to stay in Sakhalin or move to the [[Russian Far East]] rather than leave for South Korea, as they have come to consider Russia their home country. The Sakhalin Koreans' family connections in South Korea have benefited even those who remained on Sakhalin with easier access to South Korean business and imports; trade with South Korea has brought the Sakhalin Koreans a [[model minority|better economic standing]] than the average resident of Sakhalin.{{cite news |title = A battle for workers in Russia's Far East |work = International Herald Tribune |date = 2002-09-02 |url = http://www.iht.com/articles/69424.htm |accessdate = 2005-07-07 }} By 2004, inter-ethnic relations between Russians and Koreans had improved greatly and were generally not described as being a problem on Sakhalin. However, Sakhalin Koreans who have travelled to the mainland of Russia, or have relocated to there (a population of roughly 10,000), report that they have encountered various forms of racism.{{cite news|url=http://www.thesakhalintimes.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1610|title=Sakhalin's Koreans|date=2004-01-20|work=The Sakhalin Times|accessdate=2006-11-27|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061120210623/http://www.thesakhalintimes.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1610|archivedate=November 20, 2006 }} Among the Koreans who remain on Sakhalin, roughly 7,000 of the original generation of settlers survive, while their locally born descendants make up the rest of the local Korean population. They are highly urbanized; half live in the administrative centre of [[Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk]], where Koreans constitute nearly 12% of the population.{{cite news|url=http://www.thesakhalintimes.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=918 |title=Ansan Delegation visits Sakhalin |date=2004-07-30 |accessdate=2006-11-28 |work=The Sakhalin Times |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928002815/http://www.thesakhalintimes.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=918 |archivedate=September 28, 2007 }} Around thirty per cent of Sakhalin’s thirty thousand Koreans still have not taken Russian citizenship. Unlike ethnic Russians or other local minority groups, Sakhalin Koreans are exempted from [[Conscription in Russia|conscription]], but there have been calls for this exemption to be terminated.{{cite news|title=Koreans make Sakhalin multi-cultural|url=http://www.thesakhalintimes.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1982|work=The Sakhalin Times|date=2005-10-25|accessdate=2006-11-28|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061120222445/http://www.thesakhalintimes.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1982|archivedate=2006-11-20}} == Culture == ===Personal and family names=== {{Korean names in Russian}} {{see also|List of Korean family names|Cyrillization of Korean}} Korean surnames, when Cyrillized, may be spelled slightly differently from the romanisations used in the US; the resulting common pronunciations also differ, as can be seen in the table at right. Furthermore, [[Korean name|Korean naming practices]] and [[Names in Russian Empire, Soviet Union and CIS countries|Russian naming practices]] conflict in several important ways.{{cite journal|author=Kim, German Nikolaevich, and Steven Sunwoo Lee (translator)|title=Names of Koryo-saram|publisher=[[Al-Farabi University]]|url=http://www.koryosaram.freenet.kz/update1/names.doc|accessdate=2006-11-28|format=DOC |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20050306073046/http://www.koryosaram.freenet.kz/update1/names.doc |archivedate = March 6, 2005|authorlink= German Kim}} While most members of the older generations of Sakhalin Koreans used Korean names, members of the younger generations favor their Russian names. However, with the increasing exposure to South Korean pop culture, some younger Koreans have named their children after characters in [[Korean drama|Korean television dramas]]. The use of [[patronymic]]s is not widespread. In addition to Korean names, the oldest generation of Sakhalin Koreans are often legally registered under Japanese names, which they had originally adopted due to the ''[[sōshi-kaimei]]'' policy of the Japanese colonial era. After the Soviet invasion, the Sakhalin authorities conducted name registration for the local Koreans on the basis of the Japanese identity documents issued by the old Karafuto government; as of 2006, the Russian government uniformly refused requests for re-registration under [[Korean names]]. === Language === {{see also|North–South differences in the Korean language}} Due to their greater population density and expectation that they would one day be allowed to return to Korea, the Sakhalin Koreans have kept something of a sojourner mentality rather than a settler mentality, which influenced their relation to the surrounding society; even today, they tend to speak much better Korean than those who were deported to Central Asia. A weekly Korean language newspaper, the ''Saegoryeo Shinmun'' (새고려 신문), has been published since 1949, while Sakhalin Korean Broadcasting began operation in 1956. Korean-language television programmes are broadcast locally, but typically with Russian [[Subtitle (captioning)|subtitles]].{{cite news|url=http://www.hancinema.net/modele.php?page=voir_une_societe.php&id=16&news=2373#news|title="Autumn Fairy Tale" Sparks Hallyu Wave in Sakhalin|publisher=Korean Broadcasting System|date=2005-03-10|accessdate=2007-01-22}} Additionally, during the Soviet era, Sakhalin Koreans were often hired to act as announcers and writers for official media aimed at the [[Koryo-saram]] in Central Asia. However, unlike the [[Koryo-saram]], the spoken [[Korean language|Korean]] of Sakhalin is not very closely related to [[Hamgyŏng dialect]] or [[Koryo-mar]], but is instead descended from [[Jeolla dialect|Jeolla]] and [[Gyeongsang dialect]]s. As a result of the diplomatic situation up until the 1980s, during which South Korea had no relations with the Soviet Union, Korean-language instructional materials were provided by North Korea or developed domestically. Oddly enough, as a result, Sakhalin Koreans' writing, like that of Koryo-saram, follows the North Korean standard, but their spoken Korean in radio broadcasts has come to resemble the [[Seoul dialect]] of South Korea.{{cite journal|author=Kim, German Nikolaevich|title=О родном языке корейцев Казахстана (About the native language of Koreans in Kazakhstan)|url=http://world.lib.ru/k/kim_o_i/rtg1rtf.shtml|publisher=[[Al-Farabi University]]|date=2004-12-09|accessdate=2006-11-26|authorlink=German Kim|language=ru}} === Religion === Since the dissolution of the Soviet Union, there has been significant growth in religious activities among the Sakhalin Koreans; the establishment of churches was noted in scholarly articles as early as 1990.{{cite journal|last=Kim|first=Yong-guk|title=사할린에 한인교회 설립 (Establishment of Korean churches on Sakhalin)|url=http://www.dbpia.co.kr/view/ar_view.asp?pid=54&isid=1567&arid=114035&topMenu=&topMenu1=|pages=3–9|date=July 1990|issn=1227-8378|accessdate=2007-01-22|journal=North Korea|language=ko}} Christian hymns have become popular listening material, supplementing the more typical Russian, Western, and Korean pop music.{{cite journal|last=Um|first=Hae-kyung|volume=9|year=2000|title=Listening patterns and identity of the Korean diaspora in the former USSR|journal=British Journal of Ethnomusicology|pages=127–144|url=http://www.open.ac.uk/Arts/music/mclayton/bje9-2finalpdf.PDF|format=PDF|issue=2|doi=10.1080/09681220008567303}} Korean churches also broadcast religious content through Sakhalin Korean Broadcasting; a [[Baptist]] church run by ethnic Koreans sponsors a journalist there.{{cite news|url=http://www.forum18.org/Archive.php?article_id=331|publisher=[[Forum 18]]|title=RUSSIA: Local restrictions on mission in Sakhalin region|date=2004-06-01|accessdate=2007-01-22|last=Fagan|first=Geraldine}} However, large-scale religious events can be subjected to restriction by the government authorities: in June 1998 the local [[Russian Orthodox Church]] and the regional administration of Sakhalin successfully pressured [[Presbyterianism in South Korea|Korean Presbyterian]] missionaries to cancel a conference of more than 100 Presbyterian and other Protestant missionaries from around the former Soviet Union.{{cite journal|publisher=U.S. Department of State|title=Annual Report on International Religious Freedom for 1999: Russia|year=1999|url=http://www.stetson.edu/~psteeves/relnews/statedeptrussia0909.html|accessdate=2007-01-22}} Ethnic Koreans are numerous among the church-goers of St. James Cathedral, seat of the [[Apostolic Prefecture of Yuzhno Sakhalinsk]], in Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk. Catholic missions in Kholmsk and Aniva have also a fair number of Korean parishioners.{{fact|date=January 2017}} === Music === In one survey, a third of the Sakhalin Korean population expressed a preference for traditional Korean music, a far higher proportion than in any other ethnic Korean community surveyed. However, despite their better knowledge of Korean language, the same survey showed that Korean pop music is less widespread among Sakhalin Koreans than among ethnic Koreans in Kazakhstan, possessing about the same degree of popularity as in Uzbekistan. Sakhalin Koreans also reported listening to Western popular and classical music at much lower rates than Koreans in the rest of the former Soviet Union. Study of traditional Korean musical instruments has also been gaining popularity across all generations. The Ethnos Arts School was established in 1991 in Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk to teach children's classes in traditional Korean dance, piano, [[sight singing]], and the ''[[gayageum]]'', a [[zither]]-like instrument supposedly invented around the time of the [[Gaya confederacy]].{{cite news|title=사할린 고려인 학생들, 국악사랑에 흠뻑 취한 사흘: 러 사할린 에트노스예술학교 (For Sakhalin Goryeo-in, three days filled with love of Korean traditional music: Sakhalin's Ethnos Arts School)|url=http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/culture/music/52549.html|last=Chung|first=Sang-yeong|publisher=Hankyoreh|date=2005-07-25|accessdate=2007-01-21|language=ko}} == Prominent Sakhalin Koreans == * {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}} {{Use British English|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox Officeholder | honorific-prefix= | name=Sir Thomas Buxton, Bt | image=ThomasFowellBuxton.jpg | honorific-suffix = [[Order of St Michael and St George|GCMG]] [[Deputy Lieutenant|DL]] | caption= | nationality=British |birth_date = 26 January 1837 |birth_place = London, United Kingdom |death_date = {{d-da|28 October 1915|26 January 1837}} |death_place = [[Cromer]], United Kingdom | order=13th [[Governor of South Australia]] | term_start=29 October 1895 | term_end=29 March 1899 | monarch=[[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Victoria]] | premier=[[Charles Kingston (politician)|Charles Kingston]] | predecessor=[[Algernon Keith-Falconer, 9th Earl of Kintore|The Rt. Hon. Earl of Kintore]] | successor=[[Hallam Tennyson, 2nd Baron Tennyson|Lord Tennyson]]}} '''Sir Thomas Fowell Buxton, 3rd Baronet''' {{postnominals|country=GBR|GCMG|DL}} (26 January 1837 – 28 October 1915), commonly referred to as "Sir Fowell Buxton",{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article45333289 |title=Sir Fowell Bixton Ill. |newspaper=[[The Barrier Miner]] |location=Broken Hill, NSW |date=28 October 1915 |accessdate=4 November 2011 |page=1 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} was the [[Governor of South Australia]] from 29 October 1895 until 29 March 1899. He was the grandson of [[Sir Thomas Buxton, 1st Baronet|Sir Thomas Fowell Buxton]], a British MP and social reformer, and the son of [[Sir Edward Buxton, 2nd Baronet|Sir Edward North Buxton]], also an MP. He attended [[Harrow School]] and [[Trinity College, Cambridge]].{{acad|id= BKSN854TF|name=Buxton, Thomas Fowell}} He married Lady [[Lady Victoria Buxton|Victoria Noel]] on 12 June 1862 and they had a total of 13 children, ten surviving infancy. She was crippled by a spinal condition in 1869. He was elected as [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]] [[Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[King's Lynn (UK Parliament constituency)|King's Lynn]] at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1865|1865 general election]], but was defeated at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1868|1868 election]].{{cite book |last=Craig |first=F. W. S. |authorlink= F. W. S. Craig |title=British parliamentary election results 1832–1885 |origyear=1977 |edition= 2nd |year=1989 |publisher= Parliamentary Research Services |location=Chichester |isbn= 0-900178-26-4 |pages=21, 168, 388, 427 }} After his defeat, he stood again for [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament]] unsuccessfully on several other occasions: in [[Westminster (UK Parliament constituency)|Westminster]] at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1874|1874 general election]], in [[West Essex (UK Parliament constituency)|Western Essex]] at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1880|1880 general election]] and at the by-elections in [[North Norfolk (UK Parliament constituency)|Northern Norfolk]] in 1876 and 1879. He was appointed [[High Sheriff of Norfolk]] in 1876. When Buxton was appointed governor, the [[Premier of South Australia]], [[Charles Kingston]] was angry that the South Australian government had not been involved in the decision about who should be the new governor, so made life as hard as possible for Buxton and his family. The governor's allowance was reduced and customs duty was charged on their household items (including his wife's invalid carriage). Buxton took up the job anyway, and later was described as the most genial, sociable and common-sense governor, due to his gentle and unassuming friendliness. He visited gaols and hospitals, and showed genuine interest in Aboriginal culture during his time as governor. He eventually returned to England due to the ill health of his wife.{{Australian Dictionary of Biography |last= Howell |first= P. A. |authorlink= |year=1972 |id=A070518b |title= Buxton, Sir Thomas Fowell (1837–1915) |accessdate=2008-04-14 }} Their second son, [[Noel Noel-Buxton, 1st Baron Noel-Buxton|Noel Buxton]] acted as [[aide-de-camp]] to his father as governor, and later was a [[human rights]] campaigner and British [[Member of Parliament]]. A memorial to Sir Thomas and his wife Victoria was erected in St Thomas' Church in [[Upshire]] in Essex in 1917, designed by Sir [[Robert Lorimer]].Dictionary of Scottish Architects: Robert Lorimer ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==References== * [http://www.merchantnetworks.com.au/genealogy/web/buxton/pafg07.htm Buxton Progenitor] ==External links== * {{Hansard-contribs | sir-thomas-buxton | Sir Thomas Buxton }} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050419025230/http://homepages.picknowl.com.au/robinson/Governors.html Robinson family history (the governor's military orderly)] {{s-start}} {{s-par|uk}} {{succession box | title = [[Member of Parliament]] for [[King's Lynn (UK Parliament constituency)|King's Lynn]] | years = [[United Kingdom general election, 1865|1865]] – [[United Kingdom general election, 1868|1868]] | with = [[Edward Stanley, 15th Earl of Derby|Lord Stanley]] | before = [[John Henry Gurney]]

[[File:Plain Language from Truthful James.png|thumb|"Plain Language from Truthful James", as it first appeared in the ''Overland Monthly'', September 1870]]
"'''The Heathen Chinee'''", originally published as "'''Plain Language from Truthful James'''", is a [[narrative poem]] by American writer [[Bret Harte]]. It was published for the first time in September 1870 in the ''[[Overland Monthly]]''.<ref name="Railton">Railton, Stephen. [http://etext.lib.virginia.edu/railton/roughingit/map/chiharte.html Harte: "The Heathen Chinee"]. ''West Meets East: Depicting the Chinese, 1860–1873''. University of Virginia. URL accessed 2006-12-12.</ref><ref name="henderson">Henderson, Victoria. Mark Canada, editor. "[http://www.uncp.edu/home/canada/work/allam/18661913/lit/harte.htm Bret Harte, 1836–1902] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061214191749/http://www.uncp.edu/home/canada/work/allam/18661913/lit/harte.htm |date=2006-12-14 }}". ''All American: Literature, History, and Culture''. University of North Carolina at Pembroke. URL accessed 2006-12-12.</ref> It was written as a [[parody]] of [[Algernon Charles Swinburne]]'s ''[[Atalanta in Calydon]]'' (1865),<ref name="Railton" /> and [[satire|satirized]] [[Sinophobia|anti-Chinese sentiment]] in northern [[California]].
The poem became popular and was frequently republished. To Harte's dismay, however, the poem reinforced racism among his readers instead of challenging it as he intended. Nevertheless, he returned to the character years later. The poem also inspired or influenced several adaptations.
==Overview== The narrative of the poem focuses on a Chinese immigrant character named Ah Sin who is playing the card game [[euchre]] with two white men on August 3 of an unspecified year. "Truthful James", one of the men who narrates the poem, observes that the other white man, Bill Nye, is cheating with a stacked deck, and with cards up his sleeve. They both seemed to think Ah Sin was childlike and did not understand the game. Nevertheless, Ah Sin plays well and soon puts down the same card that Nye had dealt to the narrator. Concluding their opponent is ''also'' cheating, Nye fights Ah Sin and discovers he has several decks hidden in his clothes.
==Composition and publication history== [[File:Bret Harte 1871 Sarony.jpg|thumb|Bret Harte in 1871, about a year after publishing "The Heathen Chinee"]] [[Mark Twain]] later recalled that Harte initially wrote the poem "for his own amusement", without intending to publish it. According to Twain, he "threw it aside, but being one day suddenly called upon for copy he sent that very piece in."<ref name=Scharnhorst52>Scharnhorst, Gary. ''Bret Harte: Opening the American Literary West''. Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press, 2000: 52. {{ISBN|0-8061-3254-X}}</ref> In writing the poem, Harte echoed and, therefore, lampooned [[Algernon Charles Swinburne]]'s 1865 verse tragedy ''Atalanta in Calydon''.<ref name=Powers289>Powers, Ron. ''Mark Twain: A Life''. New York: Free Press, 2005: 289. {{ISBN|978-0-7432-4899-0}}</ref> [[Ambrose Bierce]] claimed Harte originally sent it to him to include in his San Francisco-based ''News Letter'', but he suggested it was better suited for Harte's own journal, the ''Overland Monthly''.<ref name=Tarnoff188>Tarnoff, Ben. ''The Bohemians: Mark Twain and the San Francisco Writers Who Reinvented American Literature''. New York: The Penguin Press, 2014: 188. {{ISBN|978-1-59420-473-9}}</ref> It appeared there under its original title, "Plain Language from Truthful James" in the September 1870 issue. Its adapted name, "The [[paganism|Heathen]] Chinee", (though it echoed Harte's phrases "the heathen Chinee" and "that heathen Chinee" in the poems text) became a title in a republication in a Boston newspaper in 1871.<ref>Scott, David. ''China and the International System, 1840-1949: Power, Presence, and Perceptions in a Century of Humiliation''. Albany: State University of New York Press, 2008: 60–61. {{ISBN|978-0-7914-7627-7}}</ref>
The poem was republished several times within a short period, including in ''[[New York Evening Post]]'', ''[[Prairie Farmer]]'', ''[[New York Tribune]]'', ''[[Boston Evening Transcript]]'', ''[[Providence Journal]]'', ''[[Hartford Courant]]'', and ''[[Saturday Evening Post]]'' (published twice). The poem was also included in a book by Harte titled ''Poems'', released in January 1871. Several periodicals and books would republish the poem with illustrations.<ref name="Railton" />
In April 1870, [[James Thomas Fields]] had published a collection of Harte's stories, ''[[The Luck of Roaring Camp]] and Other Sketches'' through the [[Ticknor and Fields|Fields, Osgood, & Co.]] imprint.<ref name=Powers289/>After the sudden success of "The Heathen Chinee", Fields rushed a to produce a collection of Harte's poetry in time for the Christmas market. That book sold out of its first six editions in five days.<ref name=Tarnoff188/>
The character of Ah Sin was revived for a theatrical play co-written by Harte and Twain, ''Ah Sin''.<ref>Tarnoff, Ben. ''The Bohemians: Mark Twain and the San Francisco Writers Who Reinvented American Literature''. New York: The Penguin Press, 2014: 241. {{ISBN|978-1-59420-473-9}}</ref> The two writers had a rift by February 1877 just before completing a final draft. Twain took over the project and, as he wrote to [[William Dean Howells]], he "left hardly a foot-print of Harte in it".<ref>Scharnhorst, Gary. ''Bret Harte: Opening the American Literary West''. Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press, 2000: 127. {{ISBN|0-8061-3254-X}}</ref> Harte nevertheless attended the play's opening at the [[National Theatre (Washington, D.C.)|National Theatre]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] on May 7, 1877.<ref>Nissen, Axel. ''Bret Harte: Prince and Pauper''. University Press of Mississippi, 2000: 158. {{ISBN|1-57806-253-5}}</ref>
Near the end of his life, Harte used the characters of both Truthful James and Ah Sin in his poem "Free Silver at Angel's", a satirical response to the silver plank in the [[1896 Democratic National Convention]] platform.<ref>Scharnhorst, Gary. ''Bret Harte: Opening the American Literary West''. Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press, 2000: 214. {{ISBN|0-8061-3254-X}}</ref> Even so, when asked about the original poem in later years, Harte called the poem "trash", and "the worst [[poem]] I ever wrote, possibly the worst poem anyone ever wrote."<ref name="Scharnhorst" />
==Response== [[File:The Heathen Chinee - Currier & Ives c.1871.jpg|thumb|left|c.1871 Currier & Ives lithograph]] "Plain Language from Truthful James" (or "The Heathen Chinee") was very popular among general readers. One New York newspaper reported on the frenzy over the poem: "Strolling down Broadway... we saw a crowd of men and boys, of high and low degree, swarming about a shop-window, pushing, laughing, and struggling... Elbowing our way through the crowd, we discovered an illustrated copy of Bret Harte's poem 'The Heathen Chinee.'"<ref name=Ott200>Ott, John. ''Manufacturing the Modern Patron in Victorian California: Cultural Philanthropy, Industrial Capital, and Social Authority''. Burlington, VT: Ashgate Publishing Company, 2014: 200. {{ISBN|9781409463344}}</ref>
The poem's popularity came, in part, from the ambiguity over its race-related message. The narrator implies that the cheating of the Chinese man was no worse than that of the white man,<ref name=Powers289/> but the irony was too subtle for general readers. The message matched one Harte had written elsewhere in exposing white people's hypocrisy. As he wrote later, the Chinese "did as the Caucasian did in all respects, and, being more patient and frugal, did it a little better".<ref name=Tarnoff188/> Harte repeatedly opposed anti-Asian discrimination since as early as 1863, both privately and publicly. In 1866, for example, he wrote a letter defending the "peaceable citizens" of [[Chinatown, San Francisco|San Francisco's Chinatown]] who were "patient under abuse, and that patience, I am ashamed to say, they have to exercise continually in California".<ref name=Ott200/> After the discovery of a murdered woman in Chinatown, whose cause of death was uncertain, Harte wrote, "as her head was caved in it is thought by some physicians that she died of galloping Christianity of the malignant California type".<ref>Tarnoff, Ben. ''The Bohemians: Mark Twain and the San Francisco Writers Who Reinvented American Literature''. New York: The Penguin Press, 2014: 187. {{ISBN|978-1-59420-473-9}}</ref>
In this vein, Harte intended "Plain Language from Truthful James" to be a satire of the prevalent prejudice among [[Irish people|Irish]] laborers in northern California against the [[Overseas Chinese|Chinese immigrants]] competing for the same work. However, the predominantly [[White American|white]] [[American middle class|middle-class]] readership of the ''Overland'' and the periodicals that reprinted it interpreted and embraced the poem as mocking the Chinese. These immigrants had been drawn in by the [[California Gold Rush]] and a boom in labor jobs, but relations with American-born citizens were tense. The more recent economic downturn in California had made tensions even worse.<ref name=Powers289/> Readers took certain phrases of the poem out of context, including "we are ruined by Chinese cheap labor!", and used the poem to reinforce their own racism.<ref name=Ott201>Ott, John. ''Manufacturing the Modern Patron in Victorian California: Cultural Philanthropy, Industrial Capital, and Social Authority''. Burlington, VT: Ashgate Publishing Company, 2014: 201. {{ISBN|9781409463344}}</ref>
The poem was also frequently parodied. The poem "Three Aces", signed "Carl Byng", was published in the ''Buffalo Express'' in December 1870, not long after "Plain Language from Truthful James" first appeared.<ref>Scharnhorst, Gary. ''Bret Harte: Opening the American Literary West''. Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press, 2000: 200. {{ISBN|0-8061-3254-X}}</ref> The poem was widely attributed to Mark Twain and labeled a "feeble imitation" of Harte.<ref>Powers, Ron. ''Mark Twain: A Life''. New York: Free Press, 2005: 293. {{ISBN|978-0-7432-4899-0}}</ref> Twain angrily denied the charge and demanded a retraction, writing to the editor [[Thomas Bailey Aldrich]], "I am not in the imitation business". Harte, in turn, targeted Twain years later in his 1893 story "Ingénue of the Sierras" by creating an unsavory character named "Charley Bing", modeled after Twain. The incident was one of several in a long rivalry between the two authors.<ref>Scharnhorst, Gary. ''Bret Harte: Opening the American Literary West''. Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press, 2000: 201. {{ISBN|0-8061-3254-X}}</ref> In 1898, ''The Overland Monthly'' ran a poem making fun of Harte himself, who had moved to Europe in 1871 and never returned, for forgetting what life was like in the west.<ref>Scharnhorst, Gary. ''Bret Harte: Opening the American Literary West''. Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press, 2000: 183–184. {{ISBN|0-8061-3254-X}}</ref>
==Influence== [[File:Pitcher with King Gambrinus offering beer to Brother Jonathan and Plain Language from Truthful James (this side), Karl L. H. Muller designer, Union Porcelain Works, 1877-c.1886 - Cincinnati Art Museum - DSC04472.JPG|thumb|right|"Heathen Chinee" pitcher]] "The Heathen Chinee", as the poem was most often called, was recited in public among opponents to [[Chinese immigration to the United States|Chinese immigration]], and [[Eugene Casserly]], a [[United States Senate|Senator]] from California who was "vehemently opposed to the admission of Chinese labour", apparently thanked Harte in writing for supporting his cause.<ref name="Scharnhorst">Scharnhorst, Gary. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/2934016 "Ways That Are Dark": Appropriations of Bret Harte's "Plain Language from Truthful James"]. ''Nineteenth-Century Literature'', Vol. 51, No. 3 (December 1996), pp. 377–399.</ref> The confusion was furthered by the altered title, which allowed for a more literal reading, and the illustrations in later republications.<ref name=Ott201/> Harte's poem shaped the popular American conception of the Chinese more than any other writing at the time,<ref name="Scharnhorst"/> and made him the most popular literary figure in America in 1870.<ref name="Railton" /> The poem was especially relevant to Harte's fame as his other popular works "[[The Luck of Roaring Camp]]" and "[[The Outcasts of Poker Flat]]" which were originally published without the author's name.<ref name=Scharnhorst52/>
It inspired a series of west coast songwriters, for example, to produce songs which looked at Chinese immigrants through negative stereotypes and questioned their place in America. Some used Harte's poem word-for-word.<ref>Moon, Krystyn R. ''Yellowface: Creating the Chinese in American Popular Music and Performance, 1850–1920s''. New Brunswick, NJ: Rutgers University Press, 2005: 38–40. {{ISBN|0-8135-3506-9}}</ref> In November 1875, Union Porcelain Works in [[Long Island]] announced the release of a pitcher decorated with figures from "The Heathen Chinee". The title character was depicted with four aces falling from his sleeve.<ref>Frelinghuysen, Alice Cooney. ''American Porcelain, 1770-1920''. New York: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1989: 183. {{ISBN|0-87099-540-5}}</ref>
The influence continued for decades and spread into other authors' writings. In 1895, for example, [[Adeline Knapp]] published her short story "The Ways That Are Dark", quoting a line from the poem. In 1931, [[Earl Derr Biggers]] considered the same quote from the poem as a title for his sixth [[Charlie Chan]] novel, inspired by a movie studio executive's suggestion, "Incidentally, could you use the Bret Harte—heathen Chinee phrase of 'Ways that are dark' as a possible title for some forthcoming exploits?"<ref>Huang, Yunte. ''Charlie Chan: The Untold Story of the Honorable Detective and His Rendezvous with American History''. New York: W. W. Norton & Company, 2010: 131. {{ISBN|978-0-393-06962-4}}</ref> [[Ralph Townsend]] used the same line for his anti-Chinese book ''[[Ways That Are Dark]]''.

Eytinge and Joseph Hull *"[http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2014/04/cancelcolbert-meet-the-heathen-chinee-105495 #CancelColbert, Meet 'the Heathen Chinee': Stephen Colbert, viral racism and 150 years of not getting the joke]" by Ben Tarnoff, ''Politico'' (April 8, 2014) * "[https://www.jstor.org/stable/3044454 Plain Language from Bret Harte]" by Margaret Duckett, ''Nineteenth-Century Fiction'', Vol. 11, No. 4 (March 1957), pp. 241–260. * "[http://hdl.handle.net/1811/24694 Heathen Chinee: A Study of American Attitudes Toward China, 1890–1905]" by Robert McClellan * "[https://www.jstor.org/stable/967944 Equal Rights and the "Heathen 'Chinee'": Black Activism in San Francisco, 1865-1875]" by Leigh Dana Johnsen, from ''[[Western Historical Quarterly]]'', Vol. 11, No. 1 (January 1980), pp. 57–68.

est. 2,000-3,000{{Harvnb|Lacey|2007|loc=154}}. | popplace = [[Dublin]], [[Limerick]] | langs = [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[English language|English]] | rels = [[Islam]], Other }} [[File:Turkish shop in Capel Street, Dublin.jpg|thumb|right|A Turkish food market in Capel Street, [[Dublin]].]] [[File:Turkish Barber Shop in Cork, Ireland.jpg|thumb|right|A Turkish barber shop in [[Cork (city)|Cork]].]] '''Turks in Ireland''' ({{lang-tr|İrlanda Türkleri}}, {{lang-ga|Turcaigh in Éirinn}}) are [[Turkish people]] who live in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] having been born elsewhere, or are Irish-born, but have Turkish roots. By Turkish roots, this could mean roots linking back to [[Turkey]], the island of [[Cyprus]] or the communities of the [[Turkish diaspora]]. == Population == According to the 2011 Irish census, there are 1,029 Turkish nationals living in Ireland.{{citation |publisher=Central Statistics Office|title=Migration and Diversity|work=Census 2011|url=http://www.cso.ie/en/media/csoie/census/documents/census2011profile6/Profile,6,Migration,and,Diversity,entire,doc.pdf|accessdate=2013-04-15}} During the time of a 2005 strike against the [[GAMA Turkish Construction Company]], socialist news websites reported that they alone employed 900{{Harvnb|Barry|2006|loc=2}}.{{citation |author=sovietpop|periodical=Anarkismo|title= Turkish builders strike in Ireland|url=http://www.anarkismo.net/newswire.php?story_id=463|date=2005-05-11|accessdate= 2009-01-31}}{{Harvnb|Dewhurst|2009|loc=2}}. to 2,000{{citation|publisher=Socialist Party|title=GAMA Scandal: Workers fight slave wages|url=http://www.socialistparty.net/pub/pages/socialist005apr05/1.htm|accessdate=2010-09-05|last=Boyd|first=Steven|date=April 2005|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613100319/http://www.socialistparty.net/pub/pages/socialist005apr05/1.htm|archivedate=13 June 2011|df=dmy-all}} Turkish workers. The Turkish embassy may have an investment in down-playing the number of Turks in Ireland given the negative reception of [[Turks in Europe|Turks in other European countries]], such as [[Turks in Germany|German Turks]], [[Turks in the Netherlands|Dutch-Turks]] and [[Turks in France|French-Turks]]. Thus, overall the number of Turkish descendants living in Ireland is estimated at 2,000-3,000. == Organisations and associations == *[[Irish Turkish Business Association]], aims to promote the The '''Yaaku''', also called '''Mukogodo''', are a people living in the Mukogodo forest west of [[Mount Kenya]], a division of [[Laikipia District Kenya|Laikipia County]] in the [[Rift Valley Province|former Rift Valley Province]], [[Kenya]].
==Etymology== The name Yaaku is said to be a Southern Nilotic term for hunting people while Mukogodo is a Yaakunte word meaning people who live in rocks.<ref>Mhando, J., Safeguarding Endangered Oral Traditions In East Africa, Nationl Museums of Kenya [https://ich.unesco.org/doc/src/00374-EN.pdf online]</ref>
==History== ===Origins=== The Yaaku speakers moved into Kenya from southern Ethiopia.<ref>Mhando, J., Safeguarding Endangered Oral Traditions In East Africa, Nationl Museums of Kenya [https://ich.unesco.org/doc/src/00374-EN.pdf online]</ref>
===Mukogodo Assimilation=== When the Yaaku community first entered the territory they would occupy, they met a people who mostly lived by hunting and gathering. This community lived in caves and the Yaaku came to call them Mukogodo, a name which means people who live in rocks in Yaakunte.<ref>Mhando, J., Safeguarding Endangered Oral Traditions In East Africa, Nationl Museums of Kenya [https://ich.unesco.org/doc/src/00374-EN.pdf online]</ref>
==Later Interaction== The Yaaku community was later assimilated by another food producing people, a process that happened over a long period of time. During this period, the Yaaku speaking Mukogodo maintained their way of life and the Yaakunte language.<ref>Mhando, J., Safeguarding Endangered Oral Traditions In East Africa, Nationl Museums of Kenya [https://ich.unesco.org/doc/src/00374-EN.pdf online]</ref>
==Decline== ===Maasai Assimilation=== The Yaaku assimilated to the [[pastoralism|pastoralist]] culture of the [[Maasai people|Maasai]] in the first half of the twentieth century (1920's and 30's), although some still keep bees. The reason for this transition is mostly one of social prestige. The Maasai look down upon [[hunter-gatherer]] peoples, calling them [[Dorobo]] ('the ones without cattle'), and many Yaaku consider the Maasai culture superior to their own.<ref>Mhando, J., Safeguarding Endangered Oral Traditions In East Africa, Nationl Museums of Kenya [https://ich.unesco.org/doc/src/00374-EN.pdf online]</ref>
====Adoption of Maasai Language==== As a result of the decision to transition to pastoralism, the Yaaku largely gave up their [[Cushitic languages|Cushitic]] language [[Yaaku language|Yaaku]] for the [[Eastern Nilotic languages|Eastern Nilotic]] [[Maasai language]] between 1925 and 1936.<ref>Mhando, J., Safeguarding Endangered Oral Traditions In East Africa, Nationl Museums of Kenya [https://ich.unesco.org/doc/src/00374-EN.pdf online]</ref>
==Revival== *[[Yaaku language]], for details of the language and revival movement
==See also== *[[Dorobo]] *[[Language shift]]
